Detection of user accessing known malici.Data: Zeek http.log; Zeek file.log; Windows Event ID 4688
Detection of user accessing known malici.Action: Correlate Zeek http.log for connections to known malicious URLs from threat intel feeds or unusual/newly visited domains with Zeek file.log for associated downloads. Analyze Windows Event ID 4688 for process creation events related to browser downloads or execution of downloaded files. Use time series analysis on user browsing/download activity to identify anomalies following reported or suspected vishing incidents.

Installation or execution of unauthorize.Data: Windows Event ID 4688; Windows Event ID 4624; Zeek conn.log
Installation or execution of unauthorize.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 for the creation of processes associated with common remote access tools (AnyDesk, TeamViewer, Splashtop, etc.). Correlate process creation events with successful logins (Event ID 4624) or network connections (Zeek conn.log) originating from the endpoint shortly after. Monitor authentication/MFA system logs for unsolicited or unusual MFA approval events for high-value accounts and correlate with login attempts. Use frequency analysis to identify rare process executions or login attempts per user.

Outbound network connections from user e.Action: Monitor Zeek conn.log for outbound connections from endpoints to external IPs/domains not typically visited by the user or organization, especially on unusual ports. Correlate with Zeek dns.log to resolve destination domains. Use frequency analysis or correlation analysis to identify rare destination IPs/domains or bursts of connections to new destinations occurring within a timeframe (e.g., 1 hour) of a reported vishing incident or observed suspicious activity. Compare connection patterns to established baselines for user groups using descriptive statistics.

Execution of command-line interpreters o.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 on user endpoints for the creation of processes like cmd.exe, powershell.exe, or other executables run from temporary directories (%TEMP%, Downloads). Analyze command-line arguments for suspicious patterns (e.g., encoded commands, external downloads). Use descriptive statistics to identify processes/command lines with low frequency across endpoints or processes executed from unusual parent processes or locations compared to typical user behavior baselines. Flag executions occurring shortly after reported vishing incidents.
